question: Which of the following would be classified under C when calculating GDP?
options: The purchase of a new car by a car rental company
The purchase of a new construction crane by a construction company
A company buying a new office building
A homeowner mowing her own lawn
Flour purchased by a baker to make donuts
The purchase of new computer software by an accounting firm
$50.00 spent eating out at a restaurant
A barber cutting his own hair
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. The purchase of a new car by a car rental company (A) would be classified under C when calculating GDP. The answer is (A).

question: The aggregate demand curve is
options: not found by adding product demand curves horizontally or vertically
a vertical summation of market demand curves
found by adding product demand curves both horizontally and vertically
a horizontal subtraction of firm demand curves
a simple aggregation of demand curves for individual goods
a vertical subtraction of market demand curves
a simple aggregation of supply curves for individual goods
a horizontal summation of firm demand curves
a horizontal summation of market demand curves
a vertical summation of firm demand curves
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. The aggregate demand curve is a vertical summation of market demand curves. The answer is (B).

question: Which of the following is a tool used by the Fed to increase the money supply?
options: Decreasing government spending.
A lower discount rate.
A higher corporate tax rate.
Selling foreign exchange reserves.
Selling Treasury securities to commercial banks.
Decreasing the minimum wage.
Selling government bonds to the public.
Increasing interest rates.
A lower personal income tax rate.
A higher reserve ratio.
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics and the Federal Reserve for help. The Federal Reserve uses open market operations to increase the money supply. Open market operations involve buying and selling government securities. The answer is (E).

question: If the world price of copper exceeds the domestic (U.S.) price of copper we would expect
options: the demand for U.S. copper to fall.
the United States to impose a tariff on imported copper to protect domestic producers.
the United States to subsidize domestic copper producers.
the United States to import more copper.
a decrease in the U.S. production of copper.
the demand for imported copper in the U.S. to fall.
a growing trade deficit in the United States in goods and services.
the domestic price of copper to increase.
the United States to be a net exporter of copper.
the United States to impose quotas on copper exports.
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on international trade for help. If the world price of copper exceeds the domestic (U.S.) price of copper, we would expect the demand for U.S. copper to fall. The answer is (A).

question: The natural rate of unemployment
options: includes structural and frictional unemployment
includes only structural and cyclical unemployment but not frictional
only includes cyclical unemployment
includes only cyclical and frictional unemployment but not structural
includes structural frictional and cyclical unemployment
only includes frictional unemployment
includes cyclical and frictional unemployment
includes structural and cyclical unemployment
does not include structural, frictional, or cyclical unemployment
only includes structural unemployment
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. The natural rate of unemployment is the rate of unemployment that would exist in the absence of frictions in the labor market. It includes structural and frictional unemployment. The answer is (A).

question: Which of the following would shift the aggregate demand curve to the right?
options: An increase in unemployment rates
A decrease in government spending
A decrease in the supply of money
An increase in savings
An increase in interest rates
Depreciation in the international value of the dollar
An increase in the price level
A decrease in consumer confidence
An increase in personal income tax rates
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. An increase in aggregate demand is associated with a shift of the aggregate demand curve to the right. The answer is (A).

question: Crowding out
options: occurs when interest rates fall due to government borrowing.
occurs when consumers and firms spend less offsetting expansionary fiscal policy.
occurs when the government reduces its spending in response to inflation.
is a consequence of contractionary fiscal policy.
is one reason fiscal policy is so effective.
is when expansionary fiscal policy leads to a decrease in interest rates.
happens when the government increases taxes to reduce the budget deficit.
causes the aggregate demand curve to shift to the right.
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. Crowding out is a phenomenon where an increase in government spending or borrowing leads to a decrease in private investment. It occurs when consumers and firms spend less offsetting expansionary fiscal policy. The answer is (B).

question: The GDP Deflator differs from the CPI in that the GDP Deflator
options: excludes goods and services not bought by consumers
incorporates current year quantities in its calculations
only incorporates current year prices in its calculations
only incorporates base year quantities in its calculations
is not affected by the change in prices over time
incorporates both current year prices and base year prices
is thought to slightly underestimate the inflation rate
uses both current and base year quantities in its calculations
is thought to slightly overestimate the inflation rate
uses base year quantities in its calculations
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. The GDP Deflator is a measure of the price level of all final goods and services produced in the economy. It is used to calculate real GDP. The CPI, on the other hand, is a measure of the price level of a fixed market basket of consumer goods and services. The GDP Deflator is a broader measure than the CPI, and it includes both current and base year quantities in its calculations. The answer is (F).

question: Marginal revenue equals marginal cost at the point where
options: total product is at its highest point
average product is at its highest point
total revenue is at its maximum, irrespective of total cost
total revenue is less than total cost
marginal product is at its highest point
average revenue equals average cost
fixed cost is at its lowest point
total revenue is equal to total cost
total revenue is greater than total cost at its greatest distance
variable cost is at its lowest point
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. Marginal revenue equals marginal cost at the point where a firm is producing at its marginal cost. This is the point where the firm is maximizing its profit. The answer is (E).

question: When the price of pears increases, we expect the following:
options: Quantity supplied of pears falls.
The price of apples falls.
There is no change in the quantity demanded or supplied.
The price of pears falls.
Quantity demanded of pears falls.
There is a surplus of pears in the market.
Quantity demanded of pears rises.
Demand for pears falls.
Quantity supplied of pears rises.
Demand for pears rises.
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. When the price of pears increases, the quantity supplied of pears will fall. The answer is (A).

question: Which of the following statements is true for a firm in a perfectly competitive industry?
options: Average revenue equals marginal revenue.
Marginal revenue is always increasing.
Average revenue is always negative.
Marginal revenue equals total revenue.
Average revenue is initially negative and then becomes positive.
Marginal revenue is decreasing.
Total revenue always decreases.
Total revenue increases and then decreases.
Total revenue equals average revenue.
Marginal revenue is initially positive and then becomes negative.
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. In a perfectly competitive market, firms in the industry have no market power and are price takers. Therefore, the average revenue for a firm in a perfectly competitive industry is equal to the market price. The marginal revenue is the revenue from the last unit sold and is equal to the market price. The answer is (A).

question: When a firm is earning a normal profit from the production of a good, it is true that
options: total revenues from production are equal to implicit costs.
total revenues from production are equal to explicit costs.
explicit costs are higher than implicit costs.
total revenues from production are equal to the sum of explicit and implicit costs.
total revenues from production are lower than the sum of explicit and implicit costs.
explicit costs are equal to implicit costs.
implicit costs are higher than explicit costs.
total revenues from production are higher than the sum of explicit and implicit costs.
total revenues from production are equal to double the sum of explicit and implicit costs.
implicit costs are equal to the difference of total revenues from production and explicit costs.
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. A normal profit is a profit that is equal to the difference between the total revenue and the total cost. In this case, the total revenue is equal to the sum of the explicit and implicit costs. The answer is (D).

question: The market for Cincinnati Reds baseball tickets is currently in equilibrium. Which of the following events would most likely increase the consumer surplus received by Reds fans?
options: The Reds decrease ticket prices due to lower stadium maintenance costs.
The Reds launch a new marketing campaign that increases ticket demand.
The Reds decide to limit the number of games in a season.
The Reds offer discounted parking for all home games.
The Reds increase ticket prices due to a rise in player salaries.
The Reds announce an increase in the price of merchandise at the stadium.
The city of Cincinnati imposes an entertainment tax on all sports events.
The Reds increase hot dog prices to reflect a higher cost of buns.
The city of Cincinnati is undertaking a huge highway construction project that strands fans in pregame traffic jams for hours.
The Reds must increase ticket prices to afford the most talented players.
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. The consumer surplus is the difference between the price a consumer is willing to pay and the price they actually pay. The event that would most likely increase the consumer surplus received by Reds fans is the one that increases the price they are willing to pay for the tickets. The answer is (A).

question: Which of the following is an example of a long-run adjustment for the owners of a small café?
options: The owners decide to outsource their bread delivery.
The owners hire several part-time workers to cover the dinner shifts.
The owners switch from whole wheat to sourdough bread.
The owners introduce a new daily special to the menu.
The owners work overtime on a busy weekend.
The owners expand their operations to include a catering service.
The owners buy the office next door, and this doubles the customer seating.
The owners negotiate a new contract with their coffee supplier.
The owners decide to close early on a slow business day.
The owners invest in a franchise opportunity and open a second location.
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. The long-run adjustment for the owners of a small café would be to expand their operations to include a catering service (F). The answer is (F).

question: A student decides that, having already spent three hours studying for an exam, she should spend one more hour studying for the same exam. Which of the following is most likely true?
options: The marginal benefit of the third hour was likely greater than the marginal benefit of the fourth hour.
The marginal cost of the third hour was likely greater than the marginal cost of the fourth hour.
The marginal benefit of the fourth hour is at least as great as the marginal cost of the fourth hour.
The marginal benefit of the fourth hour is certainly less than the marginal cost of the fourth hour.
The marginal cost of the fourth hour is at least as great as the marginal benefit of the fourth hour.
The marginal cost of the fourth hour is likely less than the marginal cost of the third hour.
The marginal benefit of the fourth hour is certainly more than the marginal cost of the fourth hour.
Without knowing the student’s opportunity cost of studying, we have no way of knowing whether or not her marginal benefits outweigh her marginal costs.
Without knowing the student's other commitments, we cannot determine the marginal cost or benefit of the fourth hour.
model_outputs: We refer to basic economic principles for help. The marginal benefit is the additional benefit derived from consuming one more unit of a good or service, and the marginal cost is the additional cost of producing one more unit of a good or service. The student has already spent three hours studying, so the marginal cost of the fourth hour is likely greater than the marginal cost of the third hour. The marginal benefit of the third hour is likely greater than the marginal benefit of the fourth hour. The answer is (A).

question: What could the government do to most effectively avoid a free rider problem?
options: Supply public goods using tax dollars
Initiate a lottery system for the usage of public goods
Enact stricter antitrust legislation
Increase the prices of public goods
Allow private companies to supply public goods
Tax those creating negative externalities
Ban the use of public goods
Provide more complete information about the relevant goods
Reduce the production of public goods
Encourage voluntary contributions for public goods
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on public goods for help. The free rider problem occurs when individuals benefit from a public good without paying for it. One way to avoid this problem is to make the cost of not contributing to the public good more expensive. One way to do this is to tax those creating negative externalities. The answer is (F).

question:
Which of the following statements are true concerning information criteria?

(i) Adjusted R-squared is an information criterion

(ii) If the residual sum of squares falls when an additional term is added, the value of the information criterion will fall

(iii) Akaike's information criterion always leads to model orders that are at least as large as those of Schwarz's information criterion

(iv) Akaike's information criterion is consistent
options: (ii) and (iv) only
(ii) and (iii) only
(i), (ii), (iii), and (iv)
(i) and (iv) only
(i) and (iii) only
(i), (iii), and (iv) only
(i) and (ii) only
(ii), (iii), and (iv) only
(iii) and (iv) only
(i), (ii), and (iii) only
model_outputs:
We refer to Wikipedia articles on econometrics for help.
(i) is true.
(ii) is true.
(iii) is true.
(iv) is true.
Thus, all of the statements are true. The answer is (C).

question: The purpose of "augmenting" the Dickey-Fuller test regression is to
options: Ensure that there is no heteroscedasticity in the test regression residuals.
Improve the accuracy of the Dickey-Fuller test
Ensure that the test regression residuals are negatively skewed
Ensure that the test regression residuals are normally distributed
Ensure that all of the non-stationarity is taken into account.
Ensure that the test regression residuals have no outliers
Ensure that the test regression residuals are positively skewed
Ensure that there is no autocorrelation in the test regression residuals
Ensure that the test regression residuals are balanced
Increase the complexity of the Dickey-Fuller test
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on econometrics for help. The purpose of "augmenting" the Dickey-Fuller test regression is to ensure that there is no autocorrelation in the test regression residuals. The answer is (H).

question: Which one of the following criticisms of the Dickey-Fuller/Engle-Granger approach to dealing with cointegrated variables is overcome by the Engle-Yoo (EY) procedure?
options: In the context of small samples, Dickey Fuller tests are prone to conclude that there is a unit root in a series when there is not
The Engle-Granger (EG) approach can only detect up to one cointegrating relationship even though there could be more than one
The variables are treated asymmetrically in the cointegrating tests
It is not possible to perform tests about the cointegrating relationship
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on econometrics for help. The Engle-Granger (EG) approach and the Dickey-Fuller/Engle-Granger approach to dealing with cointegrated variables have their own limitations. The Engle-Yoo (EY) procedure is an improvement over the EG approach and the Dickey-Fuller/Engle-Granger approach. The answer is (B).

question:
Which of the following statements are true concerning the autocorrelation function (acf) and partial autocorrelation function (pacf)?

i) The acf and pacf will always be identical at lag one whatever the model

ii) The pacf for an MA(q) model will in general be non-zero beyond lag q

iii) The pacf for an AR(p) model will be zero beyond lag p

iv) The acf and pacf will be the same at lag two for an MA(1) model
options: (i), (ii), and (iii) only
(i) and (ii) only
(ii), (iii), and (iv) only
(ii) and (iii) only
(iii) and (iv) only
(i), (iii), and (iv) only
(i), (ii), (iii), and (iv)
(ii) and (iv) only
(i) and (iv) only
(i) and (iii) only
model_outputs:
We refer to Wikipedia articles on econometrics for help.
i) The acf and pacf will always be identical at lag one whatever the model. This is true.
ii) The pacf for an MA(q) model will in general be non-zero beyond lag q. This is true.
iii) The pacf for an AR(p) model will be zero beyond lag p. This is not true. The pacf for an AR(p) model will be zero beyond lag p if the variance of the error term is constant.
iv) The acf and pacf will be the same at lag two for an MA(1) model. This is not true. The acf and pacf will be the same at lag two for an MA(1) model, but not at lag two for an MA(q) model.
The answer is (G).

question: Why do economists make seasonal adjustmentsin economic data before trying to isolate long-term trends?
options: To differentiate between urban and rural economic activity
To calculate economic growth
To understand consumer behavior
To gain a more accurate picture of the actual trend
To adjust for variations in weather patterns
To account for short-term market fluctuations
To predict future economic situations
To prepare for upcoming financial crises
To correct for data collection errors
To align with fiscal policy changes
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on econometrics for help. Seasonal adjustments in economic data are made to gain a more accurate picture of the actual trend. The answer is (D).

question: Distinguish between the transfer earnings of a piece of land andeconomic rent on a piece of land.
options: Transfer earnings and economic rent are the same
Transfer earnings are the price of land, while economic rent is the cost of using the land
Transfer earnings are what the land would earn in its best alternative use, while economic rent is anything paid over and above the transfer earnings.
Transfer earnings are the cost of land, economic rent is the revenue from land
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. Transfer earnings of a piece of land are the price that the land owner receives for the use of the land. Economic rent, on the other hand, is the price that the land owner receives for the use of the land in excess of the transfer earnings. In other words, economic rent is the price that the land owner receives for the use of the land in excess of the price that the land owner could receive for the use of the land in its best alternative use. The answer is (C).

question: The circular flow model of pure capitalism does not include an entire set of transactions which normally occur in a "real-life" economy. What set does it leave out?
options: International trades
Consumer to consumer transactions
Intra-business and intra-household transactions
Government transactions
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. The circular flow model of pure capitalism is a simplified model that represents the flow of goods and services, and money between households and firms in an economy. It does not include transactions between households and government, or between firms and government. The answer is (D).

question: Why are the industrial producing capital goods and consumer durables typically hit hardest by a recession, insofar as production and employment are concerned?
options: Postponability and monopoly power
High production cost
Inadequate infrastructure
Lack of skilled labor
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. The answer is (B).

question: "Allowing the prices of goods to rise in periods when none of the good is being produced is immoral, because the higher prices do not induce a larger output. They merely give unwarranted profits to those who are lucky enough to own the goods. Either prices should be prevented from rising or the government should take over ownership in order to prevent unjust enrichment quotas."Do you agree withthis analysis ?If so, why?If not, why not?
options: Disagree due to higher price permitting a re-allocation of existing goods
Agree due to unjust enrichment
Agree due to unwarranted profits
Disagree due to government interference
model_outputs: We refer to the principles of microeconomics for help. The analysis is based on the idea that allowing prices to rise during periods of non-production is immoral because it does not induce a larger output. This is because the higher prices do not benefit the economy, but rather give unwarranted profits to those who are lucky enough to own the goods. The analysis also suggests that either prices should be prevented from rising or the government should take over ownership in order to prevent unjust enrichment. The answer is (B).

question: Suppose a commercial bank has deposits of $400,000 and has made loans and investments of $315,000. Assume also that deposits are its only source of reserves. If the required reserve ratio is 20%, how much are its excess reserves?
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on banking for help. The required reserve ratio is the percentage of deposits that banks must hold in reserve. If the required reserve ratio is 20%, then the bank must hold 20% of its deposits in reserve. The remaining 80% of the deposits can be lent out as loans and investments. In this case, the bank has $400,000 in deposits and must hold $80,000 in reserves, so it can lend out $320,000. The answer is (A).

question: Explain the two arguments that have always been advanced fora special policy towards farmers.
options: Climate change adaptation and biotechnology
International trade and subsidies competition
Agricultural sustainability and urbanization pressures
Land reform and rural infrastructure development
Technological innovation and market expansion
National security and preserving rural life
Economic development and income generation
Food security and population control
Environmental conservation and water management
Cultural heritage and dietary diversity
model_outputs:
We refer to Wikipedia articles on agriculture for help. The two arguments that have always been advanced for a special policy towards farmers are:
(i) International trade and subsidies competition: This argument is based on the idea that farmers should be protected from international competition and that they should receive subsidies to maintain their income.
(ii) Land reform and rural infrastructure development: This argument is based on the idea that land should be redistributed to small farmers and that rural infrastructure should be developed to improve their living conditions.
The answer is (B) International trade and subsidies competition and (D) Land reform and rural infrastructure development.

question: Suppose the government decides that in order to fight inflation, labor unions will not be allowed any wage increases until further notice. What type of inflation would this be aimed at?
options: imported inflation
hyperinflation
built-in inflation
sectoral inflation
asset inflation
stagflation
deflation
wage inflation
cost-push inflation
demand-pull inflation
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. This situation is aimed at reducing built-in inflation, which is a type of inflation that is already built into the price level of goods and services. The answer is (C).

question: What important aspects of the workings of a capitalist economy are not captured in circular flow models?
options: Includes all aspects of a capitalist economy
Provides detailed explanation of flows

Omits description of principal elements, does not explain composition of flows, ignores price determination, cannot illustrate fluctuations in employment, output, and income, omits public sector, and does not highlight the effects of the use of money
Includes the effects of governmental operations and policies
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics and macroeconomics for help. Circular flow models are simplifications of the workings of a capitalist economy and do not capture all aspects of the economy. They do not include the effects of governmental operations and policies, the role of money, the determination of prices, fluctuations in employment, output, and income, and the public sector. The answer is (D).

question: What is gross private domestic investment?
options: Personal investments in real estate
Buying of stocks and bonds
Depreciation of capital
Transfer of ownership of existing assets
Government spending on infrastructure projects
Spending on research and development by foreign corporations within the country
Investment spending by domestic business firms on machinery, equipment, tools, construction, and changes in inventories
Imports of goods and services
Exports of goods and services
Consumer spending on durable goods
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. Gross private domestic investment is the sum of investment spending by domestic business firms on machinery, equipment, tools, construction, and changes in inventories. The answer is (G).

question: What is Market Socialism?
options: An economic system incorporating features of capitalistic markets and socialist planning, characterized by state ownership of land and capital, state-determined investment, market-set wages, and some income redistribution.
A system where the market dictates all aspects of the economy, including social welfare and public goods provision
An economic system characterized by complete state ownership of all industries, with prices and production centrally planned
A purely capitalistic system
A theoretical model where private individuals own resources and engage in voluntary exchanges, but profits are redistributed by the state
A mixed economic system with equal distribution of personal wealth regardless of individual contribution or market dynamics
An economic system where the government solely determines production, investment, and prices without any market influence
A system with no state intervention
A system where only the private sector determines investment
A form of socialism with worker-managed firms competing in free markets without any government intervention
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on economics for help. Market socialism is an economic system that incorporates features of capitalistic markets and socialist planning. It is characterized by state ownership of land and capital, state-determined investment, market-set wages, and some income redistribution. The answer is (A).

question: What is Fascism as an economic system?
options: Fascism promotes a mixed economy where the state owns some means of production, but there is also significant private enterprise
Fascist economies are characterized by complete state ownership of all means of production, similar to a communist system
Fascist system retains the institutional forms of a capitalist economy while subjecting these institutions to extensive control and regulation by the government.
Fascism is a system where the means of production are owned and managed by worker collectives
Fascism supports a laissez-faire approach with minimal government intervention in the economy
Fascism is a purely capitalist system
Fascism is an anarchic system without any government control
Fascist economic systems are identified by their promotion of free trade and open markets internationally
Fascism is based on the principle of universal basic income and the redistribution of wealth
Fascism is a form of socialist economy
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. Fascism is characterized by a strong centralized government, often led by a dictator, and a corporatist economic system. The state plays a significant role in the economy, but private enterprise is also allowed. The state controls key industries and resources, and there is a strong emphasis on nationalism and the glorification of the nation. The answer is (C).

question: When the population of a country consumes 90% of its income, and its technology is such that, at the margin, a $100 billion increase in its capital stock increases its output by $25 billion, what would you expect the growth rate of this society to be?
options: 4% per year
7% per year
5% per year
1% per year
3% per year
0.5% per year
2.5% per year
1.5% per year
6% per year
8% per year
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. The answer is (B).

question: What is the Quantity Equation of Exchange?
options: M = PQ/V
PQ = MV
PQ \equiv M/V
PQ = M + V
V = PQ/M
P/Q = MV
QV = PM
PM/Q = V
P + Q = MV
PQ \equiv MV
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. The Quantity Equation of Exchange is a fundamental principle in economics that states that the total quantity of goods and services produced in an economy is equal to the total quantity of money in circulation multiplied by the average price level. The answer is (B).

question: What is the potential impact on the money supply of an open market sale by the FED of $3,000,000 in government bonds, assuming all commercial banks are fully "loaned up" (i.e., their excess reserves are zero), and the re-quired reserve ratio is 25%?
options: $6,000,000 reduction
$12,000,000 reduction
$20,000,000 reduction
$3,000,000 increase
$8,000,000 reduction
$15,000,000 reduction
No impact on the money supply
$3,000,000 reduction
$24,000,000 reduction
$9,000,000 reduction
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. The FED sells government bonds in the open market, which means that commercial banks will have less reserves. The required reserve ratio is 25%, so the reduction in reserves will be 75%. The answer is (E) $8,000,000 reduction.

question: In socialist (or communist) economic theory, the system of E.Libermanhas been introduced for efficiency purposes. What isLibermanism?
options: Libermanism is an economic system without any form of centralization.
Libermanism is the introduction of competitive markets in all sectors of the economy.
Libermanism is a system where the state allocates resources based on social welfare metrics rather than profit.
Libermanism is a form of laissez-faire capitalism.
Libermanism is an economic system that prioritizes environmental sustainability over profit.
Libermanism is an economic policy that implements universal basic income to replace employment income.
Libermanism is a framework for international trade that eliminates tariffs and quotas in favor of free-market principles.
Libermanism is a theory advocating for the complete elimination of state-owned enterprises.
Libermanism is the evaluation of enterprise efficiency using the 'profit' criterion within a centralized command economy.
Libermanism is a purely profit-driven economic system.
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. E. Liberman was a Soviet economist who proposed a system of economic planning in the Soviet Union. The main idea of Libermanism is to introduce competitive markets in all sectors of the economy, while the state would still play a role in planning and allocating resources. The answer is (B).

question: What is meant by near-money? Give an example.
options: Near-monies are physical currencies
Near-monies are long-term investment bonds
Near-monies are commodities used for barter
Near-monies are precious metals such as gold and silver
Near-monies are ownership stakes in real estate
Near-monies are digital currencies
Near-monies are assets that can be quickly converted into currency or demand deposits, like savings accounts.
Near-monies are non-convertible assets
Near-monies are insurance policies with cash value
Near-monies are credit instruments such as personal loans
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on economics for help. Near-money refers to assets that can be quickly converted into currency or demand deposits, like savings accounts. The answer is (G).

question: What are the three sources of money creation?
options: Central banks, investment banks, insurance companies
Foreign exchange, bonds, mutual funds
Private businesses, government, factories
United States Treasury, Federal Reserve Banks, commercial banks
Commodity markets, sovereign wealth funds, state governments
Peer-to-peer lending, crowd funding platforms, derivative markets
Stock market, real estate, gold
Credit unions, savings and loans, pension funds
Cryptocurrencies, online payment platforms, venture capital
Consumer spending, international trade, public taxation
model_outputs:
We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. The three sources of money creation are:
1. Central banks
2. Commercial banks
3. Private businesses
The answer is (D).

question: What is the chief reason why farm policy was notconceived assimply part of an overall income distribution policy?
options: Geographic diversity of farming regions
Environmental concerns
Consumer preference for organic produce
Lack of funding
Technological advancements in agriculture
Public demand for food security
International trade agreements
Historical context
Influences from the agricultural industry
Political decisions
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on agricultural policy for help. The chief reason why farm policy was not conceived as simply part of an overall income distribution policy is that farm policy is designed to support the agricultural industry, which is a separate sector from income distribution policy. The answer is (I).

question: Suppose the government seeks to achieve a balanced budgetby levying taxes of $100 billion and making expendituresof $100 billion. How will this affect NNP if MPC = 0.8?
options: Decrease of $500 billion in NNP
Increase of $500 billion in NNP
Decrease of $100 billion in NNP
No change in NNP because taxes cancel out expenditures
Increase of $200 billion in NNP
Decrease of $80 billion in NNP
Increase of $100 billion in NNP
Increase of $50 billion in NNP
No change in NNP
Decrease of $20 billion in NNP

The government's tax revenue and expenditure affect the NNP. If the government levies taxes of $100 billion and makes expenditures of $100 billion, the NNP will remain the same. The answer is (D).

question: Explain how the MC = MR rule can be applied to the hiring of laborin a perfectly competitive market.
options: Firms hire an unlimited number of workers as long as they contribute any positive amount to total revenue.
In a perfectly competitive market, firms don't hire workers based on MRC = MRP rule.
MRC = MRP for labor and a firm will pay each worker a wage equal to the MRP of the last worker hired.
Firms hire workers until the wage rate is equal to the average cost of labor.
Firms hire workers based on a fixed wage, regardless of marginal revenue or marginal costs.
Firms pay each worker a wage equal to the total revenue of the company.
Marginal revenue product of labor is ignored, and firms focus on minimizing the average cost of labor per worker.
Firms hire workers until the marginal cost of labor exceeds the marginal revenue product of labor.
Each worker's wage is set by the average revenue product of all workers combined.
MRC = MRP and firms pay each worker a wage higher than the MRP of the last worker hired.
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. The MC = MR rule states that the marginal cost of a good equals the marginal revenue from producing one more unit of that good. In a perfectly competitive market, firms hire workers based on the marginal revenue product of labor (MRPL) and the marginal cost of labor (MCL). The wage rate is set equal to the MRPL, which is the difference between the total revenue and total cost. The answer is (C).

question: Why is it that interest payments on government bonds are not included as income currently earned, particularly, when interest on the bonds of private firms is included in na-tional income as earned income?
options: Interest on government bonds is classified as a loan repayment rather than income
Interest on government bonds is reinvested and not paid out
Interest on government bonds is tax-free

Interest paid on such debt does not reflect the generation of any current output or income

The interest on government bonds is counted as part of the budget deficit, not national income
Interest on government bonds is considered a transfer payment within the public sector
Government bonds are not considered as income
Government bonds are not part of the national income
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. Interest payments on government bonds are not included as income currently earned because they are not considered as income. The interest payments are a form of a transfer payment from the government to the bondholders, not a form of income generated by the economy. The answer is (H).

question: What is meant by a bank loan that is called a 7 percent discount?
options: A 7 percent discount loan means the interest is reduced by 7 percent from the standard rate.

question: Enumerate the cause of the long-and short-run farm problems.
options: High elasticity of demand and supply

question: Suppose we are told that an industry is composed of a small number of firms. Can we immediately call this industry oligopolistic? Explain.
options: An oligopoly is determined solely by the size and number of firms, without considering market dynamics or inter-firm interactions.

An oligopoly is characterized by many small firms that each hold a negligible fraction of the market share.
An oligopoly is defined by having a single firm with significant market power, while the rest have very little influence.
An oligopoly exists when there are many sellers in a market, each with a differentiated product.
An oligopoly is defined by the number of firms in an industry.
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. An oligopoly is a market structure characterized by a small number of firms, which are interdependent and must consider each other's actions when making decisions. The presence of many firms does not necessarily make an industry an oligopoly. The answer is (C).

question: Ricardo's theory of distribution assumed that the supply of land was fixed, while the country's population and cap-ital stock were constantly increasing. On the basis of these assumptions, he predicted eventual stagnation of the economy. How would this happen according to Ricardo?
options: The increasing population results in a surplus of land.
Landlords decrease rent prices to encourage more farming, leading to an economic boom.
The increasing population leads to increased demand for land, which eventually leads to a decline in profits, resulting in economic stagnation and decline.
The fixed supply of land has no impact on the economy, as technological advancements ensure sustained productivity.
Capital stock diminishes over time, leading to a reduction in the workforce and a stagnant economy.
The constant increase in capital stock leads to a technological revolution that offsets any negative effects of a fixed supply of land.
Landlords invest their incomes leading to economic growth.
The fixed supply of land leads to increased innovation in agriculture, which results in perpetual economic expansion.
The fixed supply of land leads to a decrease in demand.
The increasing population leads to a decrease in wages, which in turn increases the overall savings and investment, resulting in economic growth.
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on Ricardo's theory of distribution for help. According to Ricardo's theory, the fixed supply of land leads to an increase in population and capital stock, which in turn leads to an increase in demand for land. This, in turn, leads to a decline in profits, resulting in economic stagnation and decline. The answer is (C).

question: Give the significance of the equilibrium level of output.

model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. The equilibrium level of output is the level where supply and demand are in balance. The answer is (B).

question: What is a deflationary gap?
options: A situation where total demand is too small to absorb the total supply that an economy can produce at full employment level.
A gap that occurs when the government's budget deficit is too large
The excess of actual unemployment over the natural rate of unemployment
An economic condition characterized by a sudden increase in asset prices

A state where the money supply grows faster than the economy's productive capacity
A scenario where total demand exceeds the total supply
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. A deflationary gap is a situation where total demand is too small to absorb the total supply that an economy can produce at full employment level. The answer is (A).

question: Whatare the differencebetween Marginal Fixed Cost (MFC), Marginal Variable Cost (MVC) and Marginal Total Cost (MC)?
options: MFC = 0, MVC = MC
MFC decreases as output increases, MVC = 0
MFC = MVC, MC increases as output decreases
MFC = MC, MVC increases with each additional unit produced
MFC = MC, MVC = 0
MFC increases as output increases, MVC = MC
MFC = MVC = MC
MFC = 0, MVC increases with each additional unit produced, MC = MFC + MVC
MFC > MVC, MC = MFC + MVC
MFC = MVC, MC = 0
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. Marginal Fixed Cost (MFC) is the cost of producing one additional unit of output, which is the cost of the fixed costs divided by the number of units produced. Marginal Variable Cost (MVC) is the cost of producing one additional unit of output, which is the cost of the variable costs divided by the number of units produced. Marginal Total Cost (MC) is the cost of producing one additional unit of output, which is the sum of MFC and MVC. The answer is (H).

question: What is absolute advantage?
options: Absolute advantage is determined by the size of a country's population.

question: Consumer preferences determine what will be produced in purecapitalism. For what types of goods might this system ofexpressing individual wants be inadequate?

The answer is (G), (J), and (E).

question: If the capital/output ratio is 2.5, and GNP rises from $985 billionto $1,055 billion, by how much can investment be expectedto increase, assuming no depreciation? Also, if themarginal propensity to consume is 0.5, what will be the extrachanges in GNP induced by the original rise?
options: $100 billion and $200 billion
$200 billion and $400 billion
$150 billion and $300 billion
$175 billion and $350 billion
$160 billion and $320 billion
$140 billion and $280 billion
$125 billion and $250 billion
$220 billion and $440 billion
$130 billion and $260 billion
$190 billion and $380 billion
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. The capital/output ratio is the ratio of the value of capital to the value of output. If the capital/output ratio is 2.5, it means that for every $1 of output, there is $2.5 of capital. If GNP rises from $985 billion to $1,055 billion, the increase in output is $70 billion. If the capital/output ratio is 2.5, the increase in capital is $175 billion. Therefore, the increase in investment is $175 billion. The marginal propensity to consume is the fraction of income that is spent on consumption. If the marginal propensity to consume is 0.5, it means that for every $1 of income, $0.5 is spent on consumption. Therefore, the increase in consumption is $25 billion. The increase in GNP induced by the original rise is $70 billion + $25 billion = $95 billion. The answer is (H).

question: What is the inflation tax ?

The inflation tax is a one-time surcharge on savings to reduce the money supply and combat inflation.
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. The inflation tax is the reduced purchasing power of money held by the public due to an increase in the overall price level. The answer is (F).

question: What is the economic definition of \textquotedblleftland\textquotedblright?

question: In corporation XY sales in year 197X amount to $3,000,000; the cost of goods sold is $1,500,000; administrative ex-penses are $300,000; depreciation $800,000; all other ex-penses are $100,000; retained earnings are $100,000; when the corporation income tax rate is 48%, how much dividend is declared? How much could be declared if the tax rate fell to 45%?
model_outputs:
We refer to Wikipedia articles on corporate finance for help. The formula for calculating dividends is:
Dividends = Net Income - Taxes
Net income is calculated as follows:
Net Income = Sales - COGS - Administrative expenses - Depreciation - All other expenses - Retained earnings
Net Income = $3,000,000 - $1,500,000 - $300,000 - $800,000 - $100,000 - $100,000
Net Income = $1,000,000
Tax rate is 48%, so the amount of taxes is:
Taxes = Net Income * Tax rate
Taxes = $1,000,000 * 0.48
Taxes = $480,000
Dividends = Net Income - Taxes
Dividends = $1,000,000 - $480,000
Dividends = $520,000
If the tax rate falls to 45%, the amount of taxes is:
Taxes = $1,000,000 * 0.45
Taxes = $450,000
Dividends = Net Income - Taxes
Dividends = $1,000,000 - $450,000
Dividends = $550,000
The answer is (B).

question: Tariffs and quotas
options: result in lower domestic prices.
sometimes raise and sometimes lower the amount of the product sold domestically.
lower the amount of the product sold domestically.
raise the amount of the product sold domestically.

Tariffs are taxes on imported goods, while quotas limit the amount of goods that can be imported. Both tariffs and quotas can raise or lower the amount of a product sold domestically, depending on the specific policy and the market conditions. The answer is (B).

question: Suppose consumers expect the price of corn to be lower in the near future while the price of seed corn and fertilizer fall. What will happen to the equilibrium price and the equilibrium quantity?

question: What is the main contrast between the short-run and long-run Phillips curve?
options: In the short run there is a negative relationship between inflation and unemployment and in the long run the relationship is positive.

model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. The Phillips curve is a graphical representation of the relationship between inflation and unemployment. In the short run, there is a negative relationship between inflation and unemployment, meaning that as unemployment increases, inflation decreases. In the long run, the relationship is positive, meaning that as unemployment increases, inflation also increases. The answer is (A).

question: Which of the following statements is true?
options: The demand for loanable funds consists of savers.

Dollars earned today have more purchasing power than dollars earned a year from today.

The supply of loanable funds consists of investors.

model_outputs:
We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help.
(A) is true.
(B) is false. Real GDP is the value of all final goods and services produced within a country during a specific period of time.
(C) is false. The supply of loanable funds is determined by the interaction of interest rates and the preferences of savers and investors.
(D) is false. Dollars earned today have the same purchasing power as dollars earned a year from today.
(E) is false. The velocity of money is the number of times that money changes hands in a given period of time.
(F) is false. The demand for loanable funds is influenced by government borrowing, but it is also driven by the preferences of savers and investors.
(G) is false. Purchasing power parity does not ensure that dollars have the same value across all time periods.
(H) is true.
(I) is false. Inflation rates are not inversely proportional to the velocity of money at all times.
The answer is (H).

question: If nominal GDP equals $5000 and real GDP equals $4000 then the GDP Deflator equals
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. The GDP Deflator is a measure of the general price level of all final goods and services produced in the economy. If nominal GDP equals $5000 and real GDP equals $4000, then the GDP Deflator equals $5000 / $4000 = 1.25. The answer is (J).

question: Suppose a nation is experiencing an annual budget surplus and uses some of this surplus to pay down part of the national debt. One potential side effect of this policy would be
options: increase interest rates and throw the economy into a recession.
increase interest rates and depreciate the nation's currency.
decrease interest rates and risk an inflationary period.
decrease interest rates and throw the economy into a recession.
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. When a nation is experiencing an annual budget surplus, it can use some of this surplus to pay down part of the national debt. This reduces the amount of money the government needs to borrow, which in turn reduces the amount of money the government needs to create to pay for the debt. This reduces the amount of money in circulation, which can lead to a decrease in interest rates. The answer is (C).

question: In a given period the average price level in the country of Sherwood tripled and Robin's income increased from $30000 to $60000. What happened to Robin's nominal and real income? Nominal Income     Real Income
options: (G) Stayed the same     Increased

(I) Stayed the same     Stayed the same
(H) Decreased     Stayed the same
(E) Decreased     Increased
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. The nominal income is the sum of the price level and the income. The real income is the income adjusted for the price level. In a given period the average price level in the country of Sherwood tripled, therefore, Robin's nominal income increased from $30000 to $60000. To find the real income, we need to adjust the nominal income for the price level. Since the price level tripled, Robin's real income decreased. The answer is (J).

question: If nominal GDP equals $6000 and the GDP deflator equals 200 then real GDP equals

The GDP deflator is a measure of the general price level of all goods and services in the economy. If nominal GDP equals $6000 and the GDP deflator equals 200, then real GDP equals $6000 / 200 = $30. The answer is (G).

question: Suppose yesterday the euro was trading on the foreign exchange market at $1.36 U.S. and today it is trading at $1.40 U.S. Which of the following is true?

If the euro is trading at a higher value today than it was yesterday, it means that more people are willing to buy euros than sell them. This is because the euro has appreciated. The answer is (F).

question: What is the main difference between the short-run and long-run Phillips curve?

question: Which of the following is an example of capital as an economic resource?

question: At a Nash equilibrium,

question: Which of the following is a characteristic of perfect competition?

question: If corn is produced in a perfectly competitive market and the government placed a price ceiling above equilibrium, which of the following would be true?

question: At the birthday party of your best friend, you see Skylar help himself to a second piece of cake. For this individual, it must be the case that

If Skylar helps himself to a second piece of cake, it means that the marginal benefit of the second piece of cake is greater than the marginal cost. The answer is (D).

question: If the government wants to establish a socially optimal price for a natural monopoly, it should select the price at which

question: Suppose that the Durbin Watson test is applied to a regression containing two explanatory variables plus a constant with 50 data points. The test statistic takes a value of 1.53. What is the appropriate conclusion?

A value of 1.53 is considered to be a value that is consistent with the null hypothesis of no autocorrelation. question: Which of the following statements is true concerning the population regression function (PRF) and sample regression function (SRF)?

The PRF is a theoretical construct, while the SRF is an empirical construct. The PRF is not used for prediction or explanation, but the SRF is. The PRF is not used to infer likely values of the SRF, but the SRF is. The PRF is not a description of the process thought to be generating the data, but the SRF is. The answer is (G).

question: Which one of the following factors is likely to lead to a relatively high degree of out-of-sample forecast accuracy?

question: If a series, y, follows a random walk with drift b, what is the optimal one-step ahead forecast of the change in y?

question: Suppose that we are interested in testing the null hypothesis that a GARCH(2,2) model can be restricted to a process with a constant conditional variance using the likelihood ratio test approach. Which of the following statements are true?

model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on econometrics for help. The likelihood ratio test is a statistical test that compares the likelihood of the observed data under two competing hypotheses. In this case, the null hypothesis is that the GARCH(2,2) model can be restricted to a process with a constant conditional variance, and the alternative hypothesis is that the GARCH(2,2) model cannot be restricted to a process with a constant conditional variance. The test statistic follows a chi-squared distribution with 2 degrees of freedom under the null hypothesis. The value of the log-likelihood function will almost always be bigger for the unrestricted model than for the restricted model. The likelihood ratio test compares the slopes of the log-likelihood function at the maximum and at the restricted parameter value. The relevant values of the log-likelihood functions are -112.3 and -118.4, and the value of the test statistic is 12.2. The answer is (D).

question: Which of the following could be used as a test for autocorrelation up to third order?

question: If OLS is applied separately to each equation that is part of a simultaneous system, the resulting estimates will be

question: What is meant by `consumer sovereignty'?

question: How does the price system help allocative efficiency? Explain how prices can act as 'feedback mechanism' to offset the depletion of resources?

The price system has no impact on allocative efficiency and serves only to generate profits for businesses

model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. The price system helps allocative efficiency by providing information about the relative scarcity of goods and services. Prices signal consumers and producers about the cost of goods and services, and help them make decisions about what to produce and consume. Prices also act as a feedback mechanism by adjusting consumer demand and producer supply in response to changes in the price of a good or service. This helps to ensure that resources are allocated to their most productive uses. The answer is (A).

question: Economists construct models for use as tools in interpret-ing andpredicting economic behavior. What are some of the dangersin the use of models?

(A) Over-simplification and over-reliance: Models can oversimplify complex economic phenomena, leading to over-reliance on them.
(B) Increased data accuracy: Models can increase data accuracy, but this is not a danger.
(C) Reduced costs: Models can reduce costs, but this is not a danger.
(D) Faster decision-making: Models can facilitate faster decision-making, but this is not a danger.
(E) Enhanced user interface friendliness: Models can enhance user interface friendliness, but this is not a danger.

The answer is (A).

question: List the three main characteristics of monopolistic competition and discuss briefly the implications of these characteristics.
options: Large number of competitors, product differentiation, free entry and exit
Unlimited competitors, product uniqueness, blocked entry and exit
High barriers to entry, perfect information, homogeneous products
Few competitors, product similarity, restricted entry
model_outputs:
We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. Monopolistic competition is a market structure characterized by many firms producing differentiated products, where each firm has some degree of market power. The three main characteristics of monopolistic competition are:
1. Many firms: In monopolistic competition, there are many firms producing differentiated products.
2. Differentiated products: Each firm produces a product that is slightly different from its competitors.
3. Free entry and exit: New firms can enter the market and existing firms can exit the market.
The implications of these characteristics are:
1. Firms have some degree of market power, which allows them to set prices above marginal cost.
2. Consumers have a wide range of choices, which allows them to find the product that best suits their needs.
3. Firms must continuously innovate and differentiate their products to maintain their market share.
The answer is (A).

question: The production of a unit of good Y requires the employment of 3 workers and 7 units of capital. The going wage is $4. The rent on a unit of capital is $1. What should be the marginal physical product of capital in order for the production to be carried out at the least cost and what is this cost if the marginal physical product of labor is $2?
options: MPPK = 0.25, total cost = $18
MPPK = 0.5, total cost = $19
MPPK = 1.5, total cost = $25
MPPK = 0.3, total cost = $17
MPPK = 0.9, total cost = $26
MPPK = 1, total cost = $21
MPPK = 0.4, total cost = $23
MPPK = 0.75, total cost = $22
MPPK = 0.8, total cost = $24
MPPK = 0.6, total cost = $20
model_outputs:
We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. The least cost of production occurs when the marginal physical product of capital equals the marginal physical product of labor. The marginal physical product of capital is the total product of capital divided by the total amount of capital.

Let's solve this problem step by step.

The production of a unit of good Y requires the employment of 3 workers and 7 units of capital.

The wage is $4, so the cost of employing 3 workers is 3 * $4 = $12.

The rent on a unit of capital is $1, so the cost of employing 7 units of capital is 7 * $1 = $7.

The total cost of production is $12 + $7 = $19.

The marginal physical product of capital is the total product of capital divided by the total amount of capital.

The total product of capital is 7 * MPPK, and the total amount of capital is 7.

Therefore, MPPK = (7 * MPPK) / 7 = MPPK.

The marginal physical product of labor is $2, so the cost of employing 3 workers is 3 * $2 = $6.

The total cost of production is $6 + $7 = $13.

The least cost of production occurs when the marginal physical product of capital equals the marginal physical product of labor.

Therefore, MPPK = $2.

The answer is (B).

question: Relate the principle of comparative advantage to the concept of opportunity cost.
options: Comparative advantage is when a country can produce a good with a lower opportunity cost than another country.

model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. The principle of comparative advantage states that a country should specialize in producing goods in which it has a comparative advantage, even if it means trading those goods for other goods that it would produce more efficiently. This principle is related to the concept of opportunity cost, which is the cost of one alternative when another alternative is chosen. The answer is (A).

question: Most discussions of growth focus on the supply aspect of growth. Explain how unemployment due to lack of demand for goods can affect growth.

question: lf American agriculture is the most efficient in the world, could the United States still import food?

question: Suppose a bank has made a total of $100,000 in loans and still has excess reserves of $25,000. If the required re-serve ratio is 10%, how much must the bank's demand deposit liabilities be? model_outputs: We refer to the concept of reserve requirement and the money multiplier for help. The bank's demand deposit liabilities are equal to the sum of loans, reserves, and excess reserves. The bank has made a total of $100,000 in loans and still has excess reserves of $25,000. The required reserve ratio is 10%, which means that for every $100 in deposits, the bank must hold $10 in reserves. The bank's demand deposit liabilities are equal to the sum of loans, reserves, and excess reserves. The answer is (B) $138,889.

question: What do property rights have to do with growth?

question: A security has a maturity value of $ 100,000; its coupon rate is 4% and its yield is required to be 8%. What would a buyer pay for this security if the security is due 5 years from now?
model_outputs:
We refer to Wikipedia articles on finance for help. The formula to calculate the present value of a bond is:
PV = C / (1 + r)^n
where PV is the present value, C is the coupon payment, r is the interest rate, and n is the number of periods.
We can plug in the values and solve for the present value:
PV = $ 400 / (1 + 0.04)^5
PV = $ 400 / (1.04)^5
PV = $ 400 / 1.2828
PV = $ 30,612.50
The answer is (C).

question: What are the three types of budget used by theU.S. govern-ment? Indicate the reason for their existence. Which isthe most indicative of macroeconomic policy problems?
options: Balanced Budget, Surplus Budget, Deficit Budget

model_outputs:

The most indicative of macroeconomic policy problems is the deficit budget. The answer is (C).

question: State one important reason why Smith's principle of the "invisible hand" does not assure the "perfect functioning," without government intervention, of the U.S. economy today.

model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on economics for help. Smith's principle of the "invisible hand" does not assure the "perfect functioning" of the U.S. economy today because it does not account for externalities affecting the economy. Externalities are negative or positive effects on society that are not reflected in market prices. The answer is (G).

question: Why are United States coins called "token money"?

question: Why is the Wagner Act (officially the National Labor Relations Act), considered to be "labor's Magna Charta"?

question: Suppose that the public wishes to hold 15 percent of its total money balances as cash, the remainder in the form of bank deposits, and banks hold cash reserves equal to 12 per-cent of the deposits. question: What is the difference between monopoly and monopsony?
options: Monopoly and monopsony are the same

model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. The difference between monopoly and monopsony is that the former is a market structure with only one seller, while the latter is a market structure with only one buyer. The answer is (B).

question: In the extreme case, $ 1,000 of new reserves put into a bank will ultimately result in an increase of $ 5,000 of bank de-posits, assuming that the reserve ratio is 20%. But in reality this is rarely the case. What stops the extreme case from being realized?
options: A decrease in the money supply by the central bank
Withdrawals of reserves from the banking system and not adhering to the reserve ratio
Low bank deposits
Excessive regulation of the banking industry
Increase in government borrowing crowding out private lending
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. The reserve ratio is the percentage of deposits that banks must hold in reserve. In the extreme case, if a bank has $1,000 in reserves and the reserve ratio is 20%, the bank would be required to hold $200,000 in reserves. However, in reality, banks do not have $200,000 in deposits, so the reserve ratio is much lower. The answer is (B).

question: What contribution did Lenin make to Marxist economic theory?
options: Expansion of the welfare state

model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on Marxist theory for help. Lenin's contribution to Marxist economic theory was the concept of the dictatorship of the proletariat, which he developed in his 1917 book "State and Revolution." The dictatorship of the proletariat is a transitional stage of government in which the working class, as the dominant class, exercises political power. The answer is (I).

question: The Federal Reserve's most important control instrument is open-market operations. How is it that selling government bonds can reduce bank reserves?
options: The bank will lose an equivalent amount of reserve balances with the Federal Reserve

The bank's lending capacity will increase without any change in reserve balances
The bank's reserve balances remain unchanged
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. Open-market operations involve the Federal Reserve buying or selling government bonds. When the Federal Reserve sells government bonds, it reduces the amount of money in circulation and increases the interest rates. This, in turn, reduces the amount of money that banks can lend, which leads to a reduction in the amount of bank reserves. The answer is (B).

question: Sigma Corporation is studying the following production meth-odtogether with its various input combinations that will produce10 dozen pairs of shoes per day. question: Distinguish economic goods from free goods, and give an example of each.
options: Economic goods require large amounts of resources to produce, such as diamonds, while free goods are created with minimal resources, like sunlight.

question: What does the Harrod-Domar model, taken with the Keynesian theory of savings, imply for the growth rates of poor countries?
options: Rich and poor countries will experience the same growth rates regardless of savings rates
Poor countries will have fluctuating growth rates independent of savings
The level of technology determines growth rates, not savings
The level of income has no impact on savings
Savings have no correlation with growth rates in any country
Rich countries will have low growth rates
Poor countries will have high growth rates
High levels of savings will always lead to high growth rates
Poor countries will have low growth rates
Poor countries can achieve high growth rates regardless of investment levels
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. The Harrod-Domar model is a model of economic growth that assumes that savings are the determinant of growth. The Keynesian theory of savings states that savings are determined by income. Therefore, the Harrod-Domar model, taken with the Keynesian theory of savings, implies that poor countries will have high growth rates. The answer is (G).

question: What, if any, are the differences between thenatureof demandfor land and, say, the nature of demand for cars?

Land has no alternative uses, while cars can be used for multiple purposes
Demand for land is more stable than for cars
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. The nature of demand for land and cars is different in several ways. The demand for land is usually for long-term investment, while the demand for cars is for short-term use. The demand for land is primarily influenced by technological advancements, while the demand for cars is not. The demand for land is a derived demand, it depends on the demand for final products which use land as a factor input, while the demand for cars is not. The demand for land is more stable than for cars. The answer is (J).

question: What is the advantage of using money in trade as compared tobarter trade?

model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help. The advantage of using money in trade as compared to barter trade is that it allows for direct exchange of goods without the need for a common measure of value. The answer is (G).

question: Assume that A. T. Hun's marginal propensity to save = marginal propensity to consume. If he makes an extra $1000 this year, and this increase in his income does not changehis marginal propensities, how much of this $1000 willMr. Hun save?
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. The marginal propensity to save (MPS) and the marginal propensity to consume (MPC) are two different measures of how much of an increase in income is saved or spent. If A. T. Hun's marginal propensity to save equals his marginal propensity to consume, then the MPS is 1. This means that for every dollar of increase in income, Hun will save 1 dollar. Therefore, if he makes an extra $1000 this year, and this increase in his income does not change his marginal propensities, he will save $1000. The answer is (B).

question: What is a command Economy?
options: A Command Economy is one where resources are allocated based on a voting system among all citizens.

question: What is meant by "economic resources" or "factorsof production"? Name three categories of resources.

question: Which of the following is included in U.S. GDP? I.   The market value of movies made in Africa by U.S. citizens II. model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. GDP is the total value of all final goods and services produced within a country in a specific time period. The market value of blue jeans made in the United States and sold in Japan (III) is included in GDP because it is produced and sold in the United States. The market value of wine made in the United States by Canadian citizens (IV) is not included in GDP because it is produced by non-U.S. citizens. The answer is (II) and (IV).

question: In what ways is contractionary fiscal policy in the United States likely to affect domestic interest rates and the international value of the dollar?

question: The effect of the spending multiplier is lessened if

question: The appropriate fiscal policy to remedy a recession is to

question: If the economy were experiencing a recessionary gap choose the option below that would be an appropriate fiscal policy to eliminate the gap and the predicted impact of the policy on real GDP and unemployment. FISCAL POLICY     REAL GDP     UNEMPLOYMENT

question: In 2004 the United States had a trade deficit of $603 billion; therefore

net exports were positive.

model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. question: Suppose the exchange rates are 0.5 British Pound per dollar; 10 Mexican Pesos per dollar; and 100 Chinese Yuan per dollar. question: Which of the following is a consequence of removal of a protective tariff on imported steel?

question: The aggregate demand curve has a negative slope in part because when the price level increases

question: You buy 100 shares in XYZ Corporation on the Internet and your broker charges you $29.95.

question: If the marginal propensity to consume is 0.8 what is the largest total increase in GDP that can result from $500 of new spending?
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. The marginal propensity to consume (MPC) is the fraction of additional income that is spent on consumption. If the MPC is 0.8, it means that for every dollar of additional income, 80 cents is spent on consumption. If we have $500 of new spending, the largest total increase in GDP that can result from this new spending is $500 * 0.8 = $400. The answer is (J).

question: Which of the following will shift the demand curve for the Mexican peso to the left?

question: Which of the following statements would "supply-side" economists disagree with?

model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. Supply-side economists argue that tax cuts can increase economic growth by encouraging investment and capital accumulation. question: Which of the following could limit the ability of a central bank to conduct expansionary monetary policy?

model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. Expansionary monetary policy is conducted by a central bank by lowering interest rates. If households carry a significant amount of cash, holding very little in checking and saving deposits, they will be less likely to borrow and spend, limiting the ability of a central bank to conduct expansionary monetary policy. The answer is (D).

question: In a private closed economy which of the following statements is true?
options: Investment is always less than savings.

model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. In a private closed economy, saving is equal to investment. Therefore, saving is always equal to investment. The answer is (H).

question: If the CPI goes to 150 from 120 then prices have

question: Which of the following is not among the methods unions use to increase wages?

question: Which of the following is true?
options: Marginal social benefit = marginal private cost + negative externality.

A. Marginal social benefit = marginal private cost + negative externality.
B. Value of externality = marginal social costs.

D. Marginal social cost = negative externality - marginal private cost.

question: Nancy has the choice to spend one hour studying for an exam, mowing the lawn for one hour at a wage of $6, or babysitting her niece for one hour at a wage of $8. If we know that Nancy has chosen to study for the exam, which of the following is true?
options: The opportunity cost of studying is $6, which is equal to the benefit received from studying.
The opportunity cost of studying is $14, which is less than the benefit received from studying.
Nancy has no other options available besides studying, mowing the lawn, or babysitting.
Nancy values studying more than earning $6 from mowing the lawn.

The benefit received from studying is less than the opportunity cost of $8.
The benefit received from studying is greater than the opportunity cost of $8.
The opportunity cost of studying is $8, but the benefit of studying is unmeasurable.
Nancy prefers babysitting to studying but chose to study instead.
model_outputs: We refer to the concept of opportunity cost for help. Opportunity cost is the cost of the next best alternative. Since Nancy has chosen to study for the exam, the opportunity cost of studying is the wage she could have earned from babysitting, which is $8. The benefit received from studying is the grade she will get from the exam. The answer is (H).

question: Which of the following is true about the relationship of the average total cost (ATC) curve and the marginal cost (MC) curve?

The MC curve intersects the ATC curve at the minimum point of the MC curve. The answer is (H).

question:

appropriate

will be identical
options: (i), (ii), and (iii) only

(ii) and (iv) only
(i) and (ii) only
(ii) and (iii) only
(ii), (iii), and (iv) only
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on econometrics for help. The standardised residuals from an estimated GARCH model are not assumed to be normally distributed. The squares of the standardised residuals are related to their lagged squared values if the GARCH model is appropriate. In practice, they are likely to have fat tails. If the GARCH model is adequate, the standardised residuals and the raw residuals will not be identical. The answer is (F).

question: Which of the following is a DISADVANTAGE of using pure time-series models (relative to structural models)?

question: Suppose that we have estimated a GARCH model for daily equity returns, and we are interested in producing a 10-day forecast of the volatility (measured by the standard deviation of returns) for use in a value at risk model. How could such a forecast most validly be calculated?
options: Produce 1, 2, 3, ..., 10 step ahead conditional variance forecasts, take the square roots of each one and multiply them
Produce a 1-step ahead conditional variance forecast, square it and multiply it by 10
Produce 1, 2, 3, ..., 10 step ahead conditional variance forecasts and add them up

Produce a 10-step ahead conditional variance forecast, take its square root
Produce a 1-step ahead conditional variance forecast and multiply it by 10
Produce 10 one-step ahead conditional variance forecasts, add them up and take the square root
Produce 1, 2, 3, ..., 10 step ahead conditional variance forecasts, add them up and divide by 10
model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on econometrics for help. We have a GARCH model for daily equity returns, and we want to produce a 10-day forecast of the volatility (measured by the standard deviation of returns) for use in a value at risk model. The most valid way to calculate this forecast is to produce 10 step ahead conditional variance forecasts, take the square roots of each one and add them up. This is because the forecast of the volatility is the sum of the forecasted variances of the returns. The answer is (I).

question: Briefly enumerate two reasons why the supply curves of the farmersare relatively inelastic.

question: Suppose there is a poll tax of $2 per head. How is this a regressive tax?

model_outputs: We refer to Wikipedia articles on microeconomics for help.
